'''Odón device''' is a [[medical device]] that assists during a [[Obstructed labour|difficult birth]]. The low-cost device consists of a plastic sleeve that is inflated around the baby's head and is used to gently pull and ease the head of the infant through the [[birth canal]].<ref name=NYT2013>McNeil, Donald G, Jr. [https://www.nytimes.com/2013/11/14/health/new-tool-to-ease-difficult-births-a-plastic-bag.html "Car Mechanic Dreams Up a Tool to Ease Births"], ''[[The New York Times]]'', November 13, 2013. Accessed November 14, 2013.</ref>
==Need== Worldwide, more than 13 million births each year face serious complications, and every day about 800 women die from preventable causes related to pregnancy and childbirth (about 300,000 annually).<ref>{{cite news|first=Jennifer|last=Yang|url=https://www.thestar.com/news/world/2013/09/28/car_mechanic_to_the_rescue_invents_device_to_help_women_give_birth.html |title=Car mechanic to the rescue: Invents device to help women give birth |work=[[Toronto Star]] |date= September 28, 2013|accessdate=November 20, 2013}}</ref> The use of forceps and other mechanical devices in the extraction of a baby in a difficult delivery can cause internal bleeding in the mother or may result in injuries to the baby's head or spine.
The Odón Device has the potential to allow for [[vaginal delivery]] in complicated pregnancies in which common medical practice would have led to a [[cesarean section]], the use of [[forceps in childbirth|forceps to extract the newborn]] or the use of a [[ventouse]] vacuum device that attaches suction cups directly to the baby's scalp.<ref name=NYT2013/> By reducing contact between the baby's skull and the birth canal, the risk of infection is also reduced.<ref name=WHO/>
==Conception== The device was developed by Jorge Odón, a car mechanic from [[Lanús]], [[Argentina]] who had seen a video describing a method to extract a loose cork from inside an empty wine bottle by inserting a plastic bag into the bottle, inflating the bag once it has enveloped the cork and then pulling out the inflated bag together with the cork. Odón conceived of the use of this same technique that evening in bed and spoke with an obstetrician who encouraged him to move ahead with the idea. The first model of the device was created by sewing a sleeve onto a cloth bag and was tested using a doll inserted into a glass jar to simulate the use of the device in the delivery process.<ref name=NYT2013/>
In complicated deliveries, the device is positioned against the baby's scalp and the lubricated sleeve is gently inserted around the baby's head. Once a marker on the device indicates that it has been positioned properly, the inner compartment of the sleeve is inflated, providing a strong grip on the baby's head. The inserter is taken away and the sleeve can be pulled with up to {{convert|19|kg}} of force to pull out the head and allow for delivery of the baby.<ref>[http://www.odondevice.org/device.php Device], Odón Device. Accessed November 14, 2013.</ref>
==Testing and development== After further testing, Odón was introduced to the chief of obstetrics at a hospital in [[Buenos Aires]] who saw the benefit of the method and arranged to have the device tested more thoroughly at an Iowa laboratory that has simulators designed to model delivery methods more realistically. Safety testing had been performed on 20 women in Argentina, all of whom had previously given birth and were experiencing uncomplicated pregnancies, including a woman who was able to deliver a baby weighing {{convert|9|lb}} with only two pushes. Further testing will be conducted on more than 250 women in [[China]], [[India]] and [[South Africa]], with a mix of pregnant women experiencing normal and complicated labor.<ref name=NYT2013/>
[[Becton Dickinson]] has agreed to manufacture and distribute the unit, and estimates that the Odón Device could be constructed for $50 per unit, and it is expected that it could be used by [[midwives]] as well as [[obstetrician]]s who would need minimal training to use the device effectively.<ref name=NYT2013/> The [[World Health Organization]] (WHO) offered favorable notices regarding the device, which was recognized for its "potential to save the lives of mothers and newborns at the time of birth".<ref name=WHO>[http://www.who.int/reproductivehealth/topics/maternal_perinatal/odon_device/en/ New, low-cost instrument for assisted vaginal delivery], [[World Health Organization]]. Accessed November 14, 2013.</ref> The WHO's Dr. Mario Merialdi called the device "exciting", saying that childbirth is an area that has had little recent progress.<ref name=NYT2013/> Dr. [[Margaret Chan]], Director-General of the WHO, described the device as "a low-cost simplified way to deliver babies, and protect mothers [that] promises to transfer life-saving capacity to rural health posts, which almost never have the facilities and staff to perform a C-section [as] the first simple new tool for assisted delivery since forceps and vacuum extractors were introduced centuries ago."<ref>[http://www.odondevice.org/excerpts-of-the-who-dg-speech.php "The WHO Director-General highlights World Health Organization work in her speech to the 65 World Health Assembly"], Odón Device. Accessed November 14, 2013.</ref>

{{short description|Point in time when the maximum rate of petroleum extraction is reached}} {{Good article}} {{Use dmy dates|date=July 2018}} <!-- ###################################### Please note this article discusses a very technical (and to some people controversial) subject and has been edited by several science and petroleum professionals. Please discuss substantial changes on the talk page before making them. ######################################### --> [[File:Hubbert peak oil plot.svg|thumb|A 1956 world oil production distribution, showing historical data and future production, proposed by [[M. King Hubbert]] – it had a peak of 12.5 billion barrels per year in about the year 2000. {{As of|2016}}, the world's oil production was 29.4 billion barrels per year (80.6 M[[Oil barrel|bbl]]/day),<ref name=EIA>{{cite web |url=https://www.eia.gov/beta/international/data/browser/#/?pa=00000000000000000000000000000000002&c=ruvvvvvfvtvnvv1vrvvvvfvvvvvvfvvvou20evvvvvvvvvvvvuvo&ct=0&tl_id=5-A&vs=INTL.57-1-AFG-TBPD.A&vo=0&v=H&start=2014&end=2016 |title=Production of Crude Oil including Lease Condensate 2016 |publisher=[[U.S. Energy Information Administration]] |format=CVS download |accessdate=27 May 2017}}</ref>, with an [[2010s oil glut|oil glut between 2014 and 2018.]]]] [[File:Hubbert Upper-Bound Peak 1956.png|thumb|Hubbert's upper-bound prediction for US crude oil production (1956), and actual [[Lower 48|lower-48]] states production through 2014]]
<!-- P1 -Introductory paragraph on Peak oil. -->'''Peak oil''' is the theorized point in time when the maximum rate of [[extraction of petroleum]] is reached, after which it is expected to enter terminal decline.<ref>{{cite journal|last1=Hirsch|first1=Robert L.|title=PEAKING OF WORLD OIL PRODUCTION: IMPACTS, MITIGATION, & RISK MANAGEMENT|journal=US Department of Energy|date=2005|pages=1–91|url=http://www.netl.doe.gov/publications/others/pdf/Oil_Peaking_NETL.pdf|accessdate=14 January 2016|display-authors=etal}}</ref> Peak oil theory is based on the observed rise, peak, fall, and depletion of [[aggregate data|aggregate]] production rate in [[oil field]]s over time. It is often confused with [[oil depletion]]; however, whereas ''depletion'' refers to a period of falling reserves and supply, ''peak oil'' refers to peak, before terminal depletion occurs. The concept of peak oil is often credited to geologist [[M. King Hubbert]] whose [[Hubbert peak theory|1956 paper]] first presented a formal theory.
<!-- P2 -economic effects -->Some observers, such as petroleum industry experts [[Kenneth S. Deffeyes]] and [[Matthew Simmons]], predicted there would be negative [[world economy|global economy]] effects after a post-peak production decline and subsequent [[price of oil|oil price]] increase because of the continued dependence of most modern industrial [[transport]], [[agriculture|agricultural]], and [[industry|industrial]] systems on the low cost and high availability of oil.<ref>{{cite book|last1=Deffeyes|first1=Kenneth S.|title=Beyond Oil: The View from Hubbert's Peak|date=2005|publisher=Hill and Wang|location=New York}}</ref><ref>{{cite book|last1=Simmons|first1=Matthew R.|title=Twilight in the Desert: The Coming Saudi Oil Shock and the World Economy|date=2005|publisher=John Wiley and Sons|location=Hoboken}}</ref> Predictions vary greatly as to what exactly these negative effects would be. While the notion that petroleum production must peak at some point is not controversial, the assertion that this must coincide with a serious economic decline, or even that the decline in production will necessarily be caused by an exhaustion of available reserves, is not universally accepted.
<!-- P3 -Timing of peak oil -->Oil production forecasts on which predictions of peak oil are based are sometimes made within a range which includes optimistic (higher production) and pessimistic (lower production) scenarios. According to the [[International Energy Agency]], conventional crude oil production peaked in 2006.<ref name=IEA2010/> A 2013 study concluded that peak oil "appears probable before 2030", and that there was a "significant risk" that it would occur before 2020,<ref name=miller2013 /> and assumed that major investments in [[alternative fuel|alternatives]] will occur before a crisis, without requiring major changes in the lifestyle of heavily oil-consuming nations. Pessimistic predictions of future oil production made after 2007 state either that the peak has already occurred,<ref name=deffeyes012007> {{cite web |url=http://www.princeton.edu/hubbert/current-events.html |title=Current Events – Join us as we watch the crisis unfolding |date=19 January 2007 |publisher=[[Princeton University]]: Beyond Oil |author=Deffeyes, Kenneth S |authorlink=Kenneth S. Deffeyes |accessdate=27 July 2008}}</ref><ref name=ewg1007>{{cite journal |url=http://www.energywatchgroup.org/wp-content/uploads/2014/02/2008-02_EWG_Oil_Report_updated.pdf |title=Crude Oil: The Supply Outlook |publisher=[[Energy Watch Group]] |date=October 2007 |author1=Zittel, Werner |author2=Schindler, Jorg |format=PDF |accessdate=27 July 2008 |id=EWG-Series No 3/2007}}</ref><ref name=cohen102007>{{cite web |url=http://www.aspo-usa.com/archives/index.php?option=com_content&task=view&id=243&Itemid=91 |title=The Perfect Storm |author=Cohen, Dave |publisher=Association for the Study of Peak Oil and Gas |date=31 October 2007 |accessdate=27 July 2008}}</ref><ref name=alklett112009>{{cite web |url=http://www.tsl.uu.se/uhdsg/Publications/PeakOilAge.pdf |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110726171422/http://www.tsl.uu.se/uhdsg/Publications/PeakOilAge.pdf |archivedate=26 July 2011 |title=The Peak of the Oil Age |author1=Kjell Aleklett |author2=Mikael Höök |author3=Kristofer Jakobsson |author4=Michael Lardelli |author5=Simon Snowden |author6=Bengt Söderbergh |publisher=Energy Policy |date=9 November 2009 |accessdate=15 November 2009}}</ref> that oil production is on the cusp of the peak, or that it will occur soon.<ref name=koppelaar092006>{{cite journal |url=http://peakoil.nl/wp-content/uploads/2006/09/asponl_2005_report.pdf |format=PDF |title=World Production and Peaking Outlook |publisher=Peakoil Nederland |author=Koppelaar, Rembrandt H.E.M. |date=September 2006 |accessdate=27 July 2008}}</ref><ref name=owen032010>{{cite journal | doi = 10.1016/j.enpol.2010.02.026 |author1=Nick A. Owen |author2=Oliver R. Inderwildi |author3=David A. King | title = The status of conventional world oil reserves—Hype or cause for concern? | year = 2010 | journal = Energy Policy | volume = 38 | page = 4743 | issue = 8}}</ref>
<!-- P4 -Peak oil global prediction -->Hubbert's original prediction that US peak oil would occur in about 1970 appeared accurate for a time, as US average annual production peaked in 1970 at 9.6 million barrels per day and mostly declined for more than 3 decades after.<ref name=EIAt>{{cite web |url=http://www.eia.gov/dnav/pet/hist/LeafHandler.ashx?n=pet&s=mcrfpus1&f=a |title=US Field Production of Crude Oil |publisher=Energy Information Administration}}</ref> However, the use of [[hydraulic fracturing]] caused US production to rebound during the 2000s, challenging the inevitability of post-peak decline for the US oil production.<ref name=":0">{{cite web|last1=Patterson|first1=Ron|title=US Oil Production Nears Previous Peak|url=http://peakoilbarrel.com/no-name-yet/|website=Peak Oil Barrel|accessdate=4 September 2015}}</ref> In addition, Hubbert's original predictions for world peak oil production proved premature.<ref name=miller2013>{{cite journal|last=Miller|first=R. G.|author2=Sorrell, S. R.|title=The future of oil supply|journal=Philosophical Transactions of the Royal Society A: Mathematical, Physical and Engineering Sciences|date=2 December 2013|volume=372|issue=2006|pages=20130179|doi=10.1098/rsta.2013.0179|pmid=24298085|url=http://rsta.royalsocietypublishing.org/content/372/2006/20130179|accessdate=7 April 2014|pmc=3866387}}</ref> Nevertheless, the rate of discovery of new petroleum deposits peaked worldwide during the 1960s and has never approached these levels since.<ref name=campbell1222000/>
==Modeling global oil production== {{Main|Hubbert peak theory}} The idea that the rate of oil production would peak and irreversibly decline is an old one. In 1919, David White, chief geologist of the [[United States Geological Survey]], wrote of US petroleum: "... the peak of production will soon be passed, possibly within 3 years."<ref>David White, "The unmined supply of petroleum in the United States," ''Transactions of the Society of Automotive Engineers'', 1919, v.14, part 1, p.227.</ref> In 1953, Eugene Ayers, a researcher for [[Gulf Oil]], projected that if US ultimate recoverable oil reserves were 100 billion barrels, then production in the US would peak no later than 1960. If ultimate recoverable were to be as high as 200 billion barrels, which he warned was wishful thinking, US peak production would come no later than 1970. Likewise for the world, he projected a peak somewhere between 1985 (one trillion barrels ultimate recoverable) and 2000 (two trillion barrels recoverable). Ayers made his projections without a mathematical model. He wrote: "But if the curve is made to look reasonable, it is quite possible to adapt mathematical expressions to it and to determine, in this way, the peak dates corresponding to various ultimate recoverable reserve numbers"<ref>Eugene Ayers,"U.S. oil outlook: how coal fits in," ''Coal Age'', August 1953, v58 n.8 p 70–73.</ref>
By observing past discoveries and production levels, and predicting future discovery trends, the geoscientist M. King Hubbert used statistical modelling in 1956 to predict that United States oil production would peak between 1965 and 1971.<ref name=mkinghubbert1956>{{cite conference |url=http://www.hubbertpeak.com/hubbert/1956/1956.pdf |title=Nuclear Energy and the Fossil Fuels 'Drilling and Production Practice' |last= Hubbert | first = Marion King |authorlink=M. King Hubbert |conference = Spring Meeting of the Southern District. Division of Production. [[American Petroleum Institute]] |publisher= [[Shell Oil Company|Shell Development Company]] |location = [[San Antonio]], [[Texas]] |pages =22–27 <!-- p. 31-36 in pdf scheme --> |date=June 1956 |accessdate=18 April 2008 |format=PDF}}</ref> This prediction appeared accurate for a time<ref>Deffeyes, Kenneth S (2002). Hubbert's Peak: The Impending World Oil Shortage. Princeton University Press. {{ISBN|0-691-09086-6}}.</ref> however during 2018 daily production of oil in the United States was exceeding daily production in 1970, the year that was previously the peak. <ref>{{cite web|title=US oil production tops 10 million barrels a day for first time since 1970|url=https://www.cnbc.com/2018/01/31/us-oil-production-tops-10-million-barrels-a-day-for-first-time-since-1970.html|website=CNBC|accessdate=24 July 2018|date=2018-01-31}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|title=New Record For US Oil Production |url= http://www.etf.com/sections/features-and-news/new-record-us-oil-production?nopaging=1|website=ETF.com|accessdate=24 July 2018}}</ref> Hubbert used a semi-[[logistic distribution|logistical]] curved model (sometimes incorrectly compared to a [[normal distribution]]). He assumed the production rate of a limited resource would follow a roughly symmetrical distribution. Depending on the limits of exploitability and market pressures, the rise or decline of resource production over time might be sharper or more stable, appear more linear or curved.<ref name=Brandt2007/> That model and its variants are now called [[Hubbert peak theory]]; they have been used to describe and predict the peak and decline of production from regions, countries, and multinational areas.<ref name=Brandt2007>{{cite journal | last= Brandt | first = Adam R. | title = Testing Hubbert | journal = Energy Policy | volume = 35 | issue = 5 |date=May 2007 | pages = 3074–3088 | format = PDF | doi = 10.1016/j.enpol.2006.11.004 | url = http://www.iaee.org/en/students/best_papers/Adam_Brandt.pdf}}</ref> The same theory has also been applied to other limited-resource production.
More recently, the term "peak oil" was popularized by [[Colin Campbell (geologist)|Colin Campbell]] and Kjell Aleklett in 2002 when they helped form the Association for the Study of Peak Oil and Gas (ASPO).<ref name=wakeford2012>{{cite web|last=Wakeford|first=Jeremy|title=Peak oil is no myth|url=http://www.engineeringnews.co.za/article/peak-oil-is-no-myth-2012-07-27|work=Engineering News|accessdate=8 April 2014}}</ref> In his publications, Hubbert used the term "peak production rate" and "peak in the rate of discoveries".<ref name=mkinghubbert1956>{{cite conference |url=http://www.hubbertpeak.com/hubbert/1956/1956.pdf |title=Nuclear Energy and the Fossil Fuels 'Drilling and Production Practice' |last= Hubbert | first = Marion King |authorlink=M. King Hubbert |conference = Spring Meeting of the Southern District. Division of Production. [[American Petroleum Institute]] |publisher= [[Shell Oil Company|Shell Development Company]] |location = [[San Antonio]], [[Texas]] |pages =22–27 <!-- p. 31-36 in pdf scheme --> |date=June 1956 |accessdate=18 April 2008 |format=PDF}}</ref>
In a 2006 analysis of Hubbert theory, it was noted that uncertainty in real world oil production amounts and confusion in definitions increases the uncertainty in general of production predictions. By comparing the fit of various other models, it was found that Hubbert's methods yielded the closest fit over all, but that none of the models were very accurate.<ref name=Brandt2007/> In 1956 Hubbert himself recommended using "a family of possible production curves" when predicting a production peak and decline curve.<ref name=mkinghubbert1956>{{cite conference |url=http://www.hubbertpeak.com/hubbert/1956/1956.pdf |title=Nuclear Energy and the Fossil Fuels 'Drilling and Production Practice' |last= Hubbert | first = Marion King |authorlink=M. King Hubbert |conference = Spring Meeting of the Southern District. Division of Production. [[American Petroleum Institute]] |publisher= [[Shell Oil Company|Shell Development Company]] |location = [[San Antonio]], [[Texas]] |pages =22–27 <!-- p. 31-36 in pdf scheme --> |date=June 1956 |accessdate=18 April 2008 |format=PDF}}</ref>
A comprehensive 2009 study of oil depletion by the UK Energy Research Centre noted:<ref>Roger Bentley et al., “Comparison of global oil supply forecasts,” UK Energy Research Centre, Review of Evidence for Global Oil Depletion, Technical Rept. 7, July 2009, p.25</ref>
{{quote | Few analysts now adhere to a symmetrical bell-shaped production curve. This is correct, as there is no natural physical reason why the production of a resource should follow such a curve and little empirical evidence that it does. | Bentley et al. | Comparison of global oil supply forecasts}}
The report noted that Hubbert had used the logistic curve because it was mathematically convenient, not because he firmly believed it to be correct. The study observed that in most cases, the asymmetric exponential model provided a better fit, and that peaks tended to occur well before half the oil had been produced, with the result that in nearly all cases, the post-peak decline was more gradual than the increase leading up to the peak.<ref>Adam Brandt, “Methods of forecasting future oil supply,” UK Energy Research Centre, Review of Evidence for Global Oil Depletion, Technical Rept. 6, July 2009, p.21</ref>
==Demand== [[File:Global oil consumption 1980-2013.png|thumbnail|Global consumption of oil 1980–2013 (Energy Information Administration)]]
The [[supply and demand|demand]] side of peak oil over time is concerned with the total quantity of oil that the global market would choose to consume at various possible market prices and how this entire listing of quantities at various prices would evolve over time. Global demand for crude oil grew an average of 1.76% per year from 1994 to 2006, with a high growth of 3.4% in 2003–2004. After reaching a high of {{convert|85.6|Moilbbl|m3}} per day in 2007, world consumption decreased in both 2008 and 2009 by a total of 1.8%, despite fuel costs plummeting in 2008.<ref>BP, Statistical Review of World Energy 2010</ref> In spite of this lull, world's demanded for oil is projected to increase 21% over 2007 levels by 2030 ({{convert|104|Moilbbl/d}} from {{convert|86|Moilbbl}}), or about 0.8% average annual growth, largely due to increases in demand from the transportation sector.<ref name=bbc062006>{{cite news |url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/business/5099400.stm |title=World oil demand 'to rise by 37%' |publisher=BBC News |date=20 June 2006 |accessdate=25 August 2008}}</ref><ref name=eia2007ieo>{{cite journal |url=http://www.eia.doe.gov/oiaf/archive/ieo07/pdf/oil.pdf |title=2007 International Energy Outlook, Ch.3. ''Petroleum and other liquid fuels'' |publisher= [[Energy Information Administration|United States Energy Information Administration]] |date=May 2007 |format=PDF |accessdate=11 July 2009}}</ref><ref>International Energy Outlook 2009</ref> According to projections by the [[International Energy Agency]] (IEA) in 2013, growth in global oil demand will be significantly outpaced by growth in production capacity over the next 5 years.<ref name=ieamtomr2013>{{cite web |url= http://www.iea.org/newsroomandevents/pressreleases/2013/may/name,38080,en.html |title= Supply shock from North American oil rippling through global markets |work=International Energy Agency |date= 14 May 2013}}</ref><ref name=time051513>{{cite news |url=http://science.time.com/2013/05/15/the-iea-says-peak-oil-is-dead-thats-bad-news-for-climate-policy/ |title=The IEA Says Peak Oil Is Dead. That's Bad News for Climate Policy |publisher=Time Magazine |date=15 May 2013}}</ref> Developments in late 2014–2015 have seen an oversupply of global markets leading to a significant drop in the price of oil.<ref>{{Cite news|title=Oil prices could keep falling due to oversupply, says IEA|url=https://www.theguardian.com/business/2015/jul/10/oil-prices-keep-falling-international-energy-agency-oversupply|newspaper=The Guardian|publisher=Guardian News and Media|accessdate=16 August 2015|date=2015-07-10}}</ref>
[[World energy resources and consumption|Energy demand]] is distributed amongst four broad sectors: transportation, [[Domestic Energy Consumption|residential]], commercial, and industrial.<ref name=eia2006aer>{{cite journal |publisher=[[Energy Information Administration|United States Energy Information Administration]] |url=http://www.eia.doe.gov/emeu/aer/pdf/pages/sec1_3.pdf |format=PDF |title=Annual Energy Review 2008 |date=29 June 2009 |accessdate=11 July 2009 |id=DOE/EIA-0384(2008)}}</ref><ref name=eia2007goc>{{cite web |url=http://www.eia.doe.gov/pub/oil_gas/petroleum/analysis_publications/oil_market_basics/demand_text.htm#Global%20Oil%20Consumption |title=Global Oil Consumption |publisher=[[Energy Information Administration|United States Energy Information Administration]] |accessdate=27 July 2008}}</ref> In terms of oil use, transportation is the largest sector and the one that has seen the largest growth in demand in recent decades. This growth has largely come from new demand for personal-use vehicles powered by [[internal combustion engine]]s.<ref name=wood082004>{{cite news |url=http://www.eia.doe.gov/pub/oil_gas/petroleum/feature_articles/2004/worldoilsupply/oilsupply04.html |title=Long-Term World Oil Supply Scenarios: The Future Is Neither as Bleak or Rosy as Some Assert |date=18 August 2004 |publisher=[[Energy Information Administration|United States Energy Information Administration]] |last=Wood |first=John H. |last2=Long |first2=Gary R. |last3=Morehouse |first3=David F. |accessdate=27 July 2008}}</ref> This sector also has the highest consumption rates, accounting for approximately 71% of the oil used in the [[United States]] in 2013.<ref>{{Cite news|last1=David|first1=Evans|title=Transport sector set to give big lift to oil demand|url=https://www.reuters.com/article/2015/03/17/us-oil-transportation-kemp-idUSKBN0MD2AR20150317|newspaper=Reuters|accessdate=18 November 2015|date=2015-03-17}}</ref> and 55% of oil use worldwide as documented in the [[Hirsch report]]. Transportation is therefore of particular interest to those seeking to mitigate the effects of peak oil. [[File:OilConsumptionpercapita.png|thumb|center|750px|Oil consumption in bbl per day per capita (darker colors represent more consumption, gray represents no data) ''(source: NationMaster statistics, 2007-01-13)'' {| style="width: 100%; font-size: 1em;" |- | valign=top | {{legend2|#800000| > 0.07}}<br> {{legend2|#a52a2a|0.07 - 0.05}}<br> {{legend2|#ff0000|0.05 - 0.035}}<br> {{legend2|#fa8072|0.035 - 0.025}}<br> {{legend2|#f08080|0.025 - 0.02}}<br> | valign=top | {{legend2|#ffb6c1|0.02 - 0.015}}<br> {{legend2|#ffebda|0.015 - 0.01}}<br> {{legend2|#ffebcf|0.01 - 0.005}}<br> {{legend2|#fff8dc|0.005 - 0.0015}}<br> {{legend2|#e6e6fa| < 0.0015}}<br> |} ]]
Although demand growth is highest in the [[developing world]],<ref name=eiaoilconsumption>{{cite web |url=http://www.eia.doe.gov/emeu/international/oilconsumption.html |title=International Petroleum (Oil) Consumption Data |publisher=[[Energy Information Administration|United States Energy Information Administration]] |accessdate=20 December 2007}}</ref> the United States is the world's largest consumer of petroleum. Between 1995 and 2005, US consumption grew from {{convert|17700000|oilbbl/d}} to {{convert|20700000|oilbbl/d}}, a {{convert|3000000|oilbbl/d}} increase. China, by comparison, increased consumption from {{convert|3400000|oilbbl/d}} to {{convert|7000000|oilbbl/d}}, an increase of {{convert|3600000|oilbbl/d}}, in the same time frame.<ref name=BP2008>{{cite journal |url=http://www.bp.com/liveassets/bp_internet/globalbp/globalbp_uk_english/reports_and_publications/statistical_energy_review_2008/STAGING/local_assets/downloads/pdf/statistical_review_of_world_energy_full_review_2008.pdf |format=PDF |title=BP Statistical Review of Energy |publisher=[[BP]] |date=June 2008 |accessdate=27 July 2008}}</ref> The [[Energy Information Administration]] (EIA) stated that gasoline usage in the United States may have peaked in 2007, in part because of increasing interest in and mandates for use of biofuels and energy efficiency.<ref> {{cite news |url=https://www.wsj.com/articles/SB123957686061311925 <!--- this article is free on the WSJ website ---> |title=Oil Industry Braces for Drop in U.S. Thirst for Gasoline |first=Russell |last= Gold |first2=Ana |last2= Campoy |date=13 April 2009 |work=The Wall Street Journal |accessdate=21 April 2009}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.thejakartaglobe.com/naturalresources/us-gas-demand-on-long-term-decline-after-hitting-06-peak/412956|title=US Gas Demand on Long-Term Decline After Hitting '06 Peak (Obsolete link, page error 404 31.7.16)|last=Associated Press|first=|date=21 December 2010|work=|newspaper=Jakarta Globe|access-date=|via=|accessdate=10 January 2011}}</ref>
As countries [[Economic development|develop]], industry and higher [[living standards]] drive up energy use, oil usage being a major component. Thriving economies, such as [[People's Republic of China|China]] and [[India]], are quickly becoming large oil consumers.<ref name=bbc070508>{{cite news |url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/business/7387203.stm |title=Oil price 'may hit $200 a barrel' |publisher=BBC News |date=7 May 2008 |accessdate=11 July 2009}}</ref> For example, China surpassed the United States as the world's largest crude oil importer in 2015.<ref>{{cite web|last1=McSpadden|first1=Kevin|title=China Has Become the World's Biggest Crude Oil Importer for the First Time|url=http://time.com/3853451/china-crude-oil-top-importer/|website=TIME|publisher=Time Inc.|accessdate=16 August 2015}}</ref> Oil consumption growth is expected to continue; however, not at previous rates, as China's economic growth is predicted to decrease from the high rates of the early part of the 21st century.<ref>{{cite web|last1=Davis|first1=Bob|title=IMF Warns of Slower China Growth Unless Beijing Speeds Up Reforms|url=https://www.wsj.com/articles/imf-annual-report-warns-of-slower-china-growth-unless-beijing-speeds-up-economic-reforms-1406768402|website=The Wall Street Journal|publisher=News Corp|accessdate=16 August 2015}}</ref> India's oil imports are expected to more than triple from 2005 levels by 2020, rising to 5 million barrels per day (790×103 m<sup>3</sup>/d).<ref>{{cite web|last1=Bush|first1=Jason|title=China And India: A Rage For Oil|url=https://www.bloomberg.com/bw/stories/2005-09-04/china-and-india-a-rage-for-oil|website=Business Week|publisher=Bloomberg L.P.|accessdate=25 July 2008}}</ref>
===Population=== [[File:World population history.svg|thumb|World population]]
Another significant factor affecting petroleum demand has been human [[population growth]]. The [[United States Census Bureau]] predicts that [[world population]] in 2030 will be almost double that of 1980.<ref name=censusworldpop> {{cite journal |url=https://www.census.gov/population/international/data/idb/worldpoptotal.php <!-- html version dead as of 07/2009: https://www.census.gov/ipc/www/idb/worldpop.html --> |title=Total Midyear Population for the World: 1950–2050 |publisher= [[United States Census Bureau]] |date=18 June 2008 |accessdate=20 December 2007}}</ref> Oil production per capita peaked in 1979 at 5.5 barrels/year but then declined to fluctuate around 4.5 barrels/year since.<ref>{{cite web|last1=Nelder|first1=Chris|title=The 21st century population crash|url=http://www.zdnet.com/article/the-21st-century-population-crash/|website=ZDNet|accessdate=16 August 2015}}</ref> In this regard, the decreasing population growth rate since the 1970s has somewhat ameliorated the per capita decline.<ref name=censusworldpop/>
===Economic growth=== Some analysts argue that the cost of oil has a profound effect on economic growth due to its pivotal role in the extraction of resources and the processing, manufacturing, and transportation of goods.<ref name="How Economic Growth Fails">{{cite web|last1=Tverberg|first1=Gail|title=How Economic Growth Fails|url=http://ourfiniteworld.com/2015/08/10/how-economic-growth-fails/|website=Our Finite World|accessdate=10 January 2016|date=2015-08-10}}</ref> As the industrial effort to extract new unconventional oil sources increases, this has a compounding negative effect on all sectors of the economy, leading to economic stagnation or even eventual contraction. Such a scenario would result in an inability for national economies to pay high oil prices, leading to declining demand and a price collapse.<ref>{{cite web|last1=Tverberg|first1=Gail|title=What's Ahead? Lower Oil Prices, Despite Higher Extraction Costs|url=http://ourfiniteworld.com/2013/11/15/whats-ahead-lower-oil-prices-despite-higher-extraction-cost/|website=Our Finite World|accessdate=10 January 2016|date=2013-11-15}}</ref>
==Supply== [[File:Global liquids and US tight oil.png|thumb|Global liquids production 2000-2015, indicating the component of US tight oil (Energy Information Administration)]]
{{quote|Our analysis suggests there are ample physical oil and liquid fuel resources for the foreseeable future. However, the rate at which new supplies can be developed and the break-even prices for those new supplies are changing. |[[International Energy Agency]]<ref>{{cite web |url= https://www.iea.org/about/faqs/oil/ |title=FAQs Oil |publisher=[[International Energy Agency|IEA]] |accessdate=11 June 2013}}</ref>}}
===Defining sources of oil=== Oil may come from conventional or unconventional sources. The terms are not strictly defined, and vary within the literature as definitions based on new technologies tend to change over time.<ref>Steve Sorrell and others, ''Global Oil Depletion'', UK Energy Research Centre, {{ISBN|1-903144-03-5}}, p.xiii, 9, 124.</ref> As a result, different oil forecasting studies have included different classes of liquid fuels. Some use the terms "conventional" oil for what is included in the model, and "unconventional" oil for classes excluded.<ref>Colin J. Campbell and Jean H. Laherrere, [http://dieoff.org/page140.htm The end of cheap oil], Scientific American, March 1998, p. 78–83</ref>
In 1956, Hubbert confined his peak oil prediction to that crude oil "producible by methods now in use."<ref name=mkinghubbert1956/> By 1962, however, his analyses included future improvements in exploration and production.<ref name="M. King Hubbert 1962 p.73-75">M. King Hubbert, ''Energy Resources''(Washington: National Academy of Sciences, 1962)Publication 1000-D, p. 73–75.</ref> All of Hubbert's analyses of peak oil specifically excluded oil manufactured from oil shale or mined from oil sands. A 2013 study predicting an early peak excluded deepwater oil, tight oil, oil with API gravity less than 17.5, and oil close to the poles, such as that on the North Slope of Alaska, all of which it defined as non-conventional.<ref>{{cite journal|last=Hallock|first=John L.|author2=Wu, Wei |author3=Hall, Charles A.S. |author4= Jefferson, Michael |title=Forecasting the limits to the availability and diversity of global conventional oil supply: Validation|journal=Energy|date=January 2014|volume=64|pages=130–153|doi=10.1016/j.energy.2013.10.075}}</ref> Some commonly used definitions for conventional and unconventional oil are detailed below.
===Conventional sources===
Conventional oil is extracted on land and offshore using standard techniques,<ref>{{cite web |url= http://www.capp.ca/canadaIndustry/oil/Pages/default.aspx |title=conventional oil definition from Canadian Association of Oil Producers |work= Crude Oil |year=2014 |accessdate=4 December 2014}}</ref> and can be categorized as light, medium, heavy, or extra heavy in grade. The exact definitions of these grades vary depending on the region from which the oil came.<ref>{{cite web |url= http://www.petroleum.co.uk/api |title= API Gravity |work= An introduction to Petroleum |year=2015 |accessdate=4 November 2015}}</ref> Light oil flows naturally to the surface or can be extracted by simply pumping it out of the ground. Heavy refers to oil that has higher density and therefore lower [[API gravity]].<ref>{{cite web|title=The Schlumberger Oilfield Glossary|url=http://www.glossary.oilfield.slb.com/en/Disciplines/Heavy-Oil.aspx|website=Schlumberger|accessdate=16 August 2015}}</ref> It does not flow easily, and its consistency is similar to that of molasses. While some of it can be produced using conventional techniques, recovery rates are better using unconventional methods.<ref>{{cite web |url= http://www.petroleum.co.uk/heavy-crude-oil |title= Heavy Crude Oil |work= An introduction to Petroleum |year=2015 |accessdate=4 November 2015}}</ref>
According to the [[International Energy Agency]], conventional crude oil production peaked in 2006, with al all-time maximum of 70 millions of [[oil barrels|barrels]] per day.<ref name=IEA2010>[[International Energy Agency]], [https://www.iea.org/publications/freepublications/publication/weo2010.pdf World Energy Outlook 2010], pages 48 and 125 ({{ISBN|9789264086241}}).</ref>
===Unconventional sources=== Oil currently considered unconventional is derived from multiple sources. * [[Tight oil]] is extracted from deposits of low-permeability rock, sometimes shale deposits but often other rock types, using [[hydraulic fracturing]], or "fracking."<ref>{{cite web|title=The Schlumberger Oilfield Glossary|url=http://www.glossary.oilfield.slb.com/en/Terms/t/tight_oil.aspx|website=Schlumberger|accessdate=6 September 2015}}</ref> It is often confused with shale oil, which is oil manufactured from the kerogen contained in an oil shale (see below), Production of tight oil has led to a resurgence of US production in recent years. U.S. tight oil production peaked in March 2015,<ref>{{cite web|last1=Mushalik|first1=Matt|title=US shale oil peak in 2015|url=http://crudeoilpeak.info/us-shale-oil-peak-in-2015|website=Crude Oil Peak|accessdate=21 April 2016}}</ref> and fell a total of 12 percent over the next 18 months. But then U.S. tight oil production rose again, and by September 2017 had exceeded the old peak, and as of October 2017, U.S. tight oil production was still rising.<ref>US Energy Information Administration, [https://www.eia.gov/petroleum/data.php#crude Estimates of tight oil production], accessed 9 December 2017.</ref> [[File:Lower 48 production 2012-17.png|thumb|US Lower 48 oil production from 2012 and anticipated decline in production to the end of 2017, with rig count (Energy Information Administration)]]
* [[Oil shale]] is a common term for sedimentary rock such as [[shale]] or [[marl]], containing [[kerogen]], a waxy oil precursor that has not yet been transformed into crude oil by the high pressures and temperatures caused by deep burial. The term "oil shale" is somewhat confusing, because what is referred to in the U.S. as "oil shale" is not really oil and the rock it is found in is generally not shale.<ref>{{cite web |title= Oil Shale |work= An introduction to Petroleum |url= http://www.petroleum.co.uk/oil-shale |accessdate=19 November 2015}}</ref> Since it is close to the surface rather than buried deep in the earth, the shale or marl is typically mined, crushed, and [[retort]]ed, producing synthetic oil from the kerogen.<ref>{{cite web|title=The Schlumberger Oilfield Glossary|url=http://www.glossary.oilfield.slb.com/en/Terms/s/shale_oil.aspx|website=Schlumberger|accessdate=6 September 2015}}</ref> Its [[Energy returned on energy invested|net energy yield]] is much lower than conventional oil, so much so that estimates of the net energy yield of shale discoveries are considered extremely unreliable.<ref>{{cite journal|last1=McGlade|first1=Christophe|last2=Speirs|first2=Jamie|last3=Sorrell|first3=Steve|title=Methods of estimating shale gas resources – Comparison, evaluation and implications|journal=Energy|date=September 2013|volume=59|pages=116–125|doi=10.1016/j.energy.2013.05.031}}</ref><ref>{{cite conference |first=Richter |last=Philipp |title=From Boom to Bust? A Critical Look at US Shale Gas Projections |format=pdf |conference=IAEE International Conference |date=13 February 2014|location=Lisbon |url= http://www.usaee.org/usaee2014/submissions/OnlineProceedings/02_IAEE_Paper_US-Shale-Gas_PhilippMRichter.pdf|access-date=29 December 2014}}</ref> * [[Oil sands]] are unconsolidated [[sandstone]] deposits containing large amounts of very viscous crude [[bitumen]] or extra-[[heavy crude oil]] that can be recovered by [[surface mining]] or by [[in-situ]] oil wells using [[Steam injection (oil industry)|steam injection]] or other techniques. It can be liquefied by [[upgrader|upgrading]], blending with [[diluent]], or by heating; and then processed by a conventional [[oil refinery]]. The recovery process requires advanced [[technology]] but is more efficient than that of oil shale. The reason is that, unlike U.S. "oil shale", Canadian oil sands actually contain oil, and the sandstones they are found in are much easier to produce oil from than shale or marl. In the [[American English|U.S. dialect of English]], these formations are often called "tar sands", but the material found in them is not tar but an extra-heavy and viscous form of oil technically known as [[bitumen]].<ref>{{cite web |title= Bitumen and Oil Sands |work= An introduction to Petroleum |url= http://www.petroleum.co.uk/bituemn |accessdate=19 November 2015}}</ref> Venezuela has [[oil sands]] deposits similar in size to those of Canada, and approximately equal to the world's reserves of conventional oil. Venezuela's [[Orinoco Belt]] tar sands are less viscous than Canada's [[Athabasca oil sands]] – meaning they can be produced by more conventional means – but they are buried too deep to be extracted by [[surface mining]]. Estimates of the recoverable reserves of the Orinoco Belt range from {{convert|100|Goilbbl|e9m3}} to {{convert|270|Goilbbl|e9m3}}. In 2009, USGS updated this value to {{convert|513|Goilbbl|m3}}.<ref name="USGS Venezuela">{{cite web|url=http://pubs.usgs.gov/fs/2009/3028/pdf/FS09-3028.pdf|title=An Estimate of Recoverable Heavy Oil Resources of the Orinoco Oil Belt, Venezuela|author1=Christopher J. Schenk |author2=Troy A. Cook |author3=Ronald R. Charpentier |author4=Richard M. Pollastro |author5=Timothy R. Klett |author6=Marilyn E. Tennyson |author7=Mark A. Kirschbaum |author8=Michael E. Brownfield |author9=Janet K. Pitman. |last-author-amp=yes |date=11 January 2010|publisher=USGS|accessdate=23 January 2010}}</ref> [[File:US Crude Oil Production and Imports.svg|thumb|United States crude oil production exceeds imports for the first time since the early 1990s]] * [[Coal liquefaction]] or [[gas to liquids]] product are liquid hydrocarbons that are [[Synthetic fuel|synthesised]] from the conversion of coal or natural gas by the [[Fischer-Tropsch process]], [[Bergius process]], or [[Karrick process]]. Currently, two companies [[SASOL]] and [[Royal Dutch Shell|Shell]], have synthetic oil technology proven to work on a commercial scale. Sasol's primary business is based on CTL (coal-to-liquid) and GTL (natural gas-to-liquid) technology, producing US$4.40 billion in revenues (FY2009). Shell has used these processes to recycle waste [[Gas flare|flare gas]] (usually burnt off at oil wells and refineries) into usable synthetic oil. However, for CTL there may be insufficient coal reserves to supply global needs for both liquid fuels and electric power generation.<ref>{{cite journal|last1=Hook & Aleklett |title=A review on coal-to-liquid fuels and its coal consumption|journal=[[International Journal of Energy Research]]|date=30 July 2009|volume=34|issue=10|pages=848–864|doi=10.1002/er.1596|url=http://urn.kb.se/resolve?urn=urn:nbn:se:uu:diva-114247}}</ref> * Minor sources include [[thermal depolymerization]], as discussed in a 2003 article in [[Discover (magazine)|''Discover'' magazine]], that could be used to manufacture oil indefinitely, out of garbage, sewage, and agricultural waste. The article claimed that the cost of the process was $15 per barrel.<ref>{{cite journal | url=http://discovermagazine.com/2003/may/featoil/ | date=1 May 2003 | author=Lemley Brad | title=Anything Into Oil | journal=[[Discover (magazine)|Discover magazine]] | accessdate =11 July 2009}}</ref> A follow-up article in 2006 stated that the cost was actually $80 per barrel, because the feedstock that had previously been considered as hazardous waste now had market value.<ref>{{cite journal | url=http://discovermagazine.com/2006/apr/anything-oil/ | date=2 April 2006 | author=Lemley Brad | title=Anything Into Oil | journal=[[Discover (magazine)|Discover magazine]] | accessdate =11 July 2009}}</ref> A 2008 news bulletin published by [[Los Alamos Laboratory]] proposed that [[hydrogen economy|hydrogen]] (possibly produced using hot fluid from nuclear reactors to [[electrolysis|split water]] into hydrogen and oxygen) in combination with [[Carbon capture and storage#Sequestration|sequestered {{co2}}]] could be used to produce [[methanol]] (CH<sub>3</sub>OH), which could then be converted into gasoline.<ref>{{cite web|last1=Ambrosiano|first1=Nancy|title=Synthetic fuel concept to steal CO2 from air|url=http://www.lanl.gov/discover/news-release-archive/2008/February/02.12.synthetic-fuel.php|website=Los Alamos National Laboratory|accessdate=16 November 2015}}</ref>
===Discoveries=== {{quote|All the easy oil and gas in the world has pretty much been found. Now comes the harder work in finding and producing oil from more challenging environments and work areas. | William J. Cummings, Exxon-Mobil company spokesman, December 2005<ref name=bostonglobe122005/>}}
{{quote|It is pretty clear that there is not much chance of finding any significant quantity of new cheap oil. Any new or unconventional oil is going to be expensive. | Lord Ron Oxburgh, a former chairman of Shell, October 2008<ref>"[https://www.wsj.com/articles/SB10001424052748704140104575057260398292350 The Next Crisis: Prepare for Peak Oil]". [[The Wall Street Journal]]. February 11, 2010.</ref>}} {{clear}}
[[File:World crude discovery production U-2200Gb LaherrereMar2015.jpg|thumbnail|World oil discoveries peaked in the 1960s]]
The peak of world oilfield discoveries occurred in the 1960s<ref name=campbell1222000> {{cite web <!-- is it reliable source? --> |url=http://energycrisis.org/de/lecture.html |title=Peak Oil Presentation at the Technical University of Clausthal |last = Campbell |first = C. J. |date=December 2000 |publisher= energycrisis.org |accessdate=21 August 2008}}</ref> at around {{convert|55|Goilbbl|m3}}(Gb)/year.<ref name=longwell2002>{{cite journal |url=http://www.worldenergysource.com/articles/pdf/longwell_WE_v5n3.pdf |title=The Future of the Oil and Gas Industry: Past Approaches, New Challenges |last = Longwell |first = Harry J. |year=2002 |journal = World Energy Magazine |volume=5 |pages= 100–104 |format = PDF |accessdate=21 August 2008 |issue=3}}</ref> According to the Association for the Study of Peak Oil and Gas (ASPO), the rate of discovery has been falling steadily since. Less than 10 Gb/yr of oil were discovered each year between 2002 and 2007.<ref>{{cite journal |url=http://www.aspo-ireland.org/contentFiles/newsletterPDFs/Newsletter80_200708.pdf |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/5ldESvbCm?url=http://www.aspo-ireland.org/contentFiles/newsletterPDFs/Newsletter80_200708.pdf |archivedate=28 November 2009 |title= The General Depletion Picture |issue=80 |year=2007 |publisher=[Association for the Study of Peak Oil and Gas] |location=Ireland |page=2 |accessdate=21 August 2008 |format=PDF}}</ref> According to a 2010 Reuters article, the annual rate of discovery of new fields has remained remarkably constant at 15–20 Gb/yr.<ref>{{cite news |url=https://www.reuters.com/article/idUSTRE61A28X20100211 |title=Oil exploration costs rocket as risks rise |agency=Reuters |author=Christopher Johnson |date=11 February 2010 |accessdate=9 September 2010}}</ref>
[[File:Revisions to US Oil Reserves 2011.png|left|thumb|Although US proved oil reserves grew by 3.8 billion barrels in 2011, even after deducting 2.07 billion barrels of production, only 8 percent of the 5.84 billion barrels of the newly booked oil was because of new field discoveries ([[Energy Information Administration|U.S. EIA]])]]
But despite the fall-off in new field discoveries, and record-high production rates, the reported proved reserves of crude oil remaining in the ground in 2014, which totaled 1,490 billion barrels, not counting Canadian heavy oil sands, were more than quadruple the 1965 proved reserves of 354 billion barrels.<ref>OPEC, [http://www.opec.org/library/Annual%20Statistical%20Bulletin/interactive/current/FileZ/Main.htm Annual Statistical/ Annual Statistical Bulletin 2014].</ref> A researcher for the [[Energy Information Administration|U.S. Energy Information Administration]] has pointed out that after the first wave of discoveries in an area, most oil and natural gas reserve growth comes not from discoveries of new fields, but from extensions and additional gas found within existing fields.<ref>David F. Morehouse, [ftp://eia.doe.gov/pub/oil_gas/natural_gas/feature_articles/1997/intricate_puzzle_oil_gas_reserves_growth/pdf/m07fa.pdf The intricate puzzle of oil and gas reserve growth], US Energy Information Administration, Natural Gas Monthly, July 1997.</ref>
A report by the UK Energy Research Centre noted that "discovery" is often used ambiguously, and explained the seeming contradiction between falling discovery rates since the 1960s and increasing reserves by the phenomenon of reserve growth. The report noted that increased reserves within a field may be discovered or developed by new technology years or decades after the original discovery. But because of the practice of "backdating," any new reserves within a field, even those to be discovered decades after the field discovery, are attributed to the year of initial field discovery, creating an illusion that discovery is not keeping pace with production.<ref>Steve Sorrell and others, ''Global Oil Depletion'', UK Energy Research Centre, {{ISBN|1-903144-03-5}}, p. 24–25.</ref>
===Reserves=== {{Main|Oil reserves|List of largest oil fields}}
[[File:Oil Reserves.png|thumb|350px|right|Proven [[oil reserves]], 2013]]
Total possible conventional crude [[oil reserves]] include crude oil with 90% certainty of being technically able to be produced from reservoirs (through a wellbore using primary, secondary, improved, enhanced, or tertiary methods); all crude with a 50% probability of being produced in the future (probable); and discovered reserves that have a 10% possibility of being produced in the future (possible). Reserve estimates based on these are referred to as 1P, proven (at least 90% probability); 2P, proven and probable (at least 50% probability); and 3P, proven, probable and possible (at least 10% probability), respectively.<ref>{{cite web|last1=Etherington et al.|first1=John|title=Comparison of Selected Reserves and Resource Classifications and Associated Definitions|url=http://www.spe.org/industry/docs/OGR_Mapping.pdf|website=Society of Petroleum Engineers|accessdate=26 September 2016}}</ref> This does not include liquids extracted from mined solids or gasses ([[oil sand]]s, [[oil shale]], [[gas to liquids|gas-to-liquid processes]], or [[coal liquefaction|coal-to-liquid processes]]).<ref name=iht072007>{{cite news |url=http://www.blnz.com/news/2007/07/16/Study_Demand_outpace_crude_supply_pply.html |title=Oil industry report says demand to outpace crude oil production |author=Herbert, Jozef|publisher= BLNZ|agency=Associated Press|date=16 July 2007|accessdate=11 July 2009}}</ref>
Hubbert's 1956 peak projection for the United States depended on geological estimates of ultimate recoverable oil resources, but starting in his 1962 publication, he concluded that ultimate oil recovery was an output of his mathematical analysis, rather than an assumption. He regarded his peak oil calculation as independent of reserve estimates.<ref>M. King Hubbert, 1962, "Energy Resources," National Academy of Sciences, Publication 1000-D, p.60.</ref><ref>M. King Hubbert, "National Academy of Sciences Report on Energy Resources: reply," AAPG Bulletin, Oct. 1965, v.49 n.10 p.1720-1727.</ref><ref>M. King Hubbert, "Degree of advancement of petroleum exploration in United States," AAPG Bulletin, Nov. 1967, v.51 n.11 p.2207-2227.</ref>
Many current 2P calculations predict reserves to be between 1150 and 1350 Gb, but some authors have written that because of misinformation, withheld information, and misleading reserve calculations, 2P reserves are likely nearer to 850–900 Gb.<ref name=ewg1007/><ref name=owen032010/> The Energy Watch Group wrote that actual reserves peaked in 1980, when production first surpassed new discoveries, that apparent increases in reserves since then are illusory, and concluded (in 2007): "Probably the world oil production has peaked already, but we cannot be sure yet."<ref name=ewg1007/> <!-- this paragraph refers to total reserves (3P), not just proved (1P), which means technically and economically producible ... that 1P reserves grow is not surprising -->
====Concerns over stated reserves==== {{quote|[World] reserves are confused and in fact inflated. Many of the so-called reserves are in fact resources. They're not delineated, they're not accessible, they're not available for production.|[[Sadad Ibrahim Al Husseini|Sadad Al Husseini]], former VP of [[Aramco]], presentation to the Oil and Money conference, October 2007.<ref name=cohen102007/>}}
[[Sadad Ibrahim Al Husseini|Sadad Al Husseini]] estimated that {{convert|300|Goilbbl}} of the world's {{convert|1200|Goilbbl}} of proven reserves should be recategorized as speculative resources.<ref name=cohen102007/>
[[File:OPEC declared reserves 1980-now EIA.svg|thumb|400px|Graph of OPEC reported reserves showing jumps in stated reserves without associated discoveries, as well as the lack of depletion despite yearly production]]
One difficulty in forecasting the date of peak oil is the opacity surrounding the oil reserves classified as "proven". In many major producing countries, the majority of reserves claims have not been subject to outside audit or examination.<ref name=bostonglobe122005> {{cite news|url=http://www.boston.com/news/world/articles/2005/12/11/price_rise_and_new_deep_water_technology_opened_up_offshore_drilling/|title=Price rise and new deep-water technology opened up offshore drilling|date=11 December 2005|last = Donnelly |first = John|work=Boston Globe|accessdate=21 August 2008}}</ref> Many worrying signs concerning the depletion of proven reserves have emerged in recent years.<ref name=boxell102004>{{cite news|url=http://www.energybulletin.net/2470.html|title=Top Oil Groups Fail to Recoup Exploration|author=Boxell, James|publisher=Energy Bulletin|work= [[The New York Times]] |date=10 October 2004 |accessdate=26 August 2008|archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20080521144405/http://www.energybulletin.net/2470.html <!-- Bot retrieved archive --> |archivedate = 21 May 2008}}</ref><ref name=gerth022004>{{cite news |url=https://www.nytimes.com/2004/02/24/business/24OIL.html |title=Forecast of Rising Oil Demand Challenges Tired Saudi Fields |author=Gerth, Jeff |work=The New York Times |date=24 February 2004 |accessdate=26 August 2008|archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20080309103717/http://www.nytimes.com/2004/02/24/business/24OIL.html <!-- Bot retrieved archive --> |archivedate = 9 March 2008}}</ref> This was best exemplified by the 2004 scandal surrounding the "evaporation" of 20% of [[Shell oil company|Shell]]'s reserves.<ref name=shellblewrep>{{cite news |url=https://www.thetimes.co.uk/article/how-shell-blew-a-hole-in-a-100-year-reputation-jdpf09mzzjw |title=How Shell blew a hole in a 100-year reputation |author=Morsfeld, Carl|date=10 October 2004|work=The Times|accessdate=26 August 2008 |location=London}} {{registration required}}</ref>
For the most part, proven reserves are stated by the oil companies, the producer states and the consumer states. All three have reasons to overstate their proven reserves: oil companies may look to increase their potential worth; producer countries gain a stronger [[international relations|international stature]]; and governments of consumer countries may seek a means to foster sentiments of [[security]] and [[inflation|stability]] within their [[economy|economies]] and among consumers.
Major discrepancies arise from accuracy issues with the self-reported numbers from the [[Organization of the Petroleum Exporting Countries]] (OPEC). Besides the possibility that these nations have overstated their reserves for political reasons (during periods of no substantial discoveries), over 70 nations also follow a practice of not reducing their reserves to account for yearly production. Analysts have suggested that OPEC member nations have economic incentives to exaggerate their reserves, as the OPEC quota system allows greater output for countries with greater reserves.<ref name=nyt08212005> {{cite news|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2005/08/21/magazine/21OIL.html|title=The Breaking Point|author=Maass Peter|work=The New York Times|date= 21 August 2005|accessdate=26 August 2008}}</ref>
[[Kuwait]], for example, was reported in the January 2006 issue of ''Petroleum Intelligence Weekly'' to have only {{convert|48|Goilbbl}} in reserve, of which only 24 were fully proven. This report was based on the leak of a confidential document from Kuwait and has not been formally denied by the Kuwaiti authorities. This leaked document is from 2001,<ref>{{cite web|title=Kuwait reserves|url=http://crudeoilpeak.info/kuwait-reserves|website=Crude Oil Peak|accessdate=16 November 2015}}</ref> but excludes revisions or discoveries made since then. Additionally, the reported {{convert|1.5|Goilbbl}} of [[Kuwaiti oil fires|oil burned off]] by Iraqi soldiers in the [[Gulf War|First Persian Gulf War]]<ref name=TEDkuwait> {{cite web |url=http://www.american.edu/TED/kuwait.htm |title=The Economic and Environmental Impact of the Gulf War on Kuwait and the Persian Gulf |publisher=[[American University]] Trade and Environment Database |author=Javed, Ali |date=1 December 2000 |accessdate=18 November 2007}}</ref> are conspicuously missing from Kuwait's figures.
On the other hand, investigative journalist [[Greg Palast]] argues that oil companies have an interest in making oil look more rare than it is, to justify higher prices.<ref name=gnn052006> {{cite news |url=http://www.gregpalast.com/madhouse/index.php/32 |title=No Peaking: The Hubbert Humbug |publisher=[[Guerrilla News Network]] |author=Palast, Greg |authorlink=Greg Palast |date=23 May 2006|accessdate=14 July 2010}}</ref> This view is contested by ecological journalist [[Richard Heinberg]].<ref name=Heinberg>{{cite web|url=http://heinberg.wordpress.com/2006/07/01/171-an-open-letter-to-greg-palast-on-peak-oil/ |title=An Open Letter to Greg Palast on Peak Oil |author=Heinberg, Richard |authorlink=Richard Heinberg |date=July 2006 |accessdate=14 July 2010}}</ref> Other analysts argue that oil producing countries understate the extent of their reserves to drive up the price.<ref name=nationalreview122003>{{cite news|url=http://www.nationalreview.com/comment/learsy200312040900.asp|title=OPEC Follies – Breaking point|author= Learsy, Raymond J.|work=[[National Review]]|date=4 December 2003|accessdate=26 August 2008|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080629004635/http://www.nationalreview.com/comment/learsy200312040900.asp <!--Added by H3llBot-->|archivedate=29 June 2008}}</ref>
The EUR reported by the 2000 USGS survey of {{convert|2300|Goilbbl}} has been criticized for assuming a discovery trend over the next twenty years that would reverse the observed trend of the past 40 years. Their 95% confidence EUR of {{convert|2300|Goilbbl}} assumed that discovery levels would stay steady, despite the fact that new-field discovery rates have declined since the 1960s. That trend of falling discoveries has continued in the ten years since the USGS made their assumption. The 2000 USGS is also criticized for other assumptions, as well as assuming 2030 production rates inconsistent with projected reserves.<ref name=ewg1007/>
====Reserves of unconventional oil==== {{Main|Unconventional oil|Heavy crude oil|Oil sands|Oil shale|Fischer-Tropsch process}}
[[File:Syncrude mildred lake plant.jpg|thumb|Syncrude's Mildred Lake mine site and plant near [[Fort McMurray]], [[Alberta]]]]
As conventional oil becomes less available, it can be replaced with production of liquids from unconventional sources such as [[tight oil]], [[oil sands]], ultra-heavy oils, [[gas-to-liquid]] technologies, [[coal-to-liquid]] technologies, biofuel technologies, and [[shale oil]].<ref>[http://www.eia.gov/forecasts/archive/ieo04/pdf/0484%282004%29.pdf IEO 2004] pg. 37</ref> In the 2007 and subsequent International Energy Outlook editions, the word "Oil" was replaced with "Liquids" in the chart of [[World energy resources and consumption|world energy consumption]].<ref>[http://www.eia.gov/forecasts/archive/ieo06/pdf/0484%282006%29.pdf IEO 2006] Figure 3. pg. 2</ref><ref>[http://www.eia.gov/forecasts/archive/ieo07/pdf/0484%282007%29.pdf IEO 2007] Figure 3. pg. 2</ref> In 2009 biofuels was included in "Liquids" instead of in "Renewables".<ref>[http://www.eia.gov/forecasts/archive/ieo09/pdf/0484%282009%29.pdf IEO 2009] Figure 2. pg. 1</ref> The inclusion of natural gas liquids, a bi-product of natural gas extraction, in "Liquids" has been criticized as it is mostly a chemical feedstock which is generally not used as transport fuel.<ref>{{cite web|last1=Mearns|first1=Euan|title=Global Oil and Other Liquid Fuels Production Update|url=http://euanmearns.com/global-oil-and-other-liquid-fuels-production-update/|website=Energy Matters|accessdate=21 August 2015|date=2014-11-03}}</ref>
[[File:Texas Oil Production 1935-2012.png|thumb|Texas oil production declined since peaking in 1972 but has recently had a resurgence due to tight oil production]]
Reserve estimates are based on the oil price. Hence, unconventional sources such as heavy crude oil, oil sands, and oil shale may be included as new techniques reduce the cost of extraction.<ref>{{cite journal|last1=Owen|first1=Nick A.|title=The status of conventional world oil reserves—Hype or cause for concern?|journal=Energy Policy|date=2010|volume=38|issue=8|pages=4743–4749|doi=10.1016/j.enpol.2010.02.026|url=http://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/pii/S0301421510001072|accessdate=24 September 2015|display-authors=etal}}</ref> With rule changes by the [[U.S. Securities and Exchange Commission|SEC]],<ref>{{cite web |url= https://www.sec.gov/rules/final/2008/33-8995.pdf|title= Modernization of Oil and Gas Reporting|work=1 January 2010 (Rule changes effective)|publisher= [[U.S. Securities and Exchange Commission|SEC]]|accessdate=29 March 2010}}</ref> oil companies can now book them as proven reserves after opening a [[strip mine]] or thermal facility for [[resource extraction|extraction]]. These unconventional sources are more labor and resource intensive to produce, however, requiring extra energy to refine, resulting in higher production costs and up to three times more [[greenhouse gas]] emissions per barrel (or barrel equivalent) on a "well to tank" basis or 10 to 45% more on a "well to wheels" basis, which includes the carbon emitted from combustion of the final product.<ref name = "MJ Herald">{{cite web |url= http://www.mjtimes.sk.ca/Canada---World/Business/2009-12-10/article-243834/Albertas-oilsands:-well-managed-necessity-or-ecological-disaster%3F/1|title= Alberta's oilsands: well-managed necessity or ecological disaster?|author= Bob Weber|publisher= Moose Jaw Herald, [[The Canadian Press]]|accessdate=29 March 2010}}</ref><ref>{{cite news |url=http://www.rigzone.com/news/article.asp?a_id=30703 |title=Canadian Tar Sands: The Good, the Bad, and the Ugly |date=28 March 2006 |author=Duarte, Joe |publisher=RigZone |accessdate=11 July 2009}}</ref>
While the energy used, resources needed, and environmental effects of extracting unconventional sources have traditionally been prohibitively high, major [[unconventional oil]] sources being considered for large-scale production are the extra heavy oil in the [[Orinoco Belt]] of [[Venezuela]],<ref>{{cite web|last1=Schenk|first1=C.J.|title=An Estimate of Recoverable Heavy Oil Resources of the Orinoco Oil Belt, Venezuela|url=http://www.pubs.usgs.gov/fs/2009/3028/pdf/FS09-3028.pdf|website=United States Geological Survey|accessdate=16 November 2015|display-authors=etal}}</ref> the [[Athabasca Oil Sands]] in the [[Western Canadian Sedimentary Basin]],<ref>{{cite web |url=http://ffden-2.phys.uaf.edu/102spring2002_Web_projects/M.Sexton/ |title=Tar Sands: A brief overview |author=Sexton, Matt |year=2003 |accessdate=11 July 2009}}</ref> and the oil shale of the [[Green River Formation]] in [[Colorado]], [[Utah]], and [[Wyoming]] in the United States.<ref name=dyni>{{Cite journal | last=Dyni | first=John R. | title=Geology and resources of some world oil-shale deposits (Presented at Symposium on Oil Shale in Tallinn, Estonia, 18–21 November 2002) | journal=[[Oil Shale (journal)|Oil Shale. A Scientific-Technical Journal]] | volume=20 | issue=3 | pages=193–252 | year=2003 | url=http://www.kirj.ee/public/oilshale/2_dyni_2003_3.pdf | format=PDF | issn=0208-189X| accessdate =17 June 2007}}</ref><ref name=fossilenergy>{{Cite journal | title =Strategic significance of America's oil shale resource. Volume II: Oil shale resources, technology and economics |author1=Johnson, Harry R. |author2=Crawford, Peter M. |author3=Bunger, James W. | publisher= Office of Deputy Assistant Secretary for Petroleum Reserves; [[Office of Naval Petroleum and Oil Shale Reserves]]; [[United States Department of Energy]] | year=2004 | url=http://www.fossil.energy.gov/programs/reserves/npr/publications/npr_strategic_significancev2.pdf | format=PDF | accessdate=23 June 2007}}</ref> Energy companies such as [[Syncrude]] and [[Suncor]] have been extracting bitumen for decades but production has increased greatly in recent years with the development of [[Steam Assisted Gravity Drainage]] and other extraction technologies.<ref>{{cite journal|author1=Qi Jiang |author2=Bruce Thornton |author3=Jen Russel-Houston |author4=Steve Spence. |title=Review of Thermal Recovery Technologies for the Clearwater and Lower Grand Rapids Formations in the Cold Lake Area in Alberta|journal=Canadian International Petroleum Conference. Osum Oil Sands Corp.|url=http://www.osumcorp.com/wp-content/uploads/2009/07/CIPC_Review-of-Thermal-Recovery-Technologies-for-the-Clearwater-and-Lower-Grand-Rapids-Formations-in-the-Cold-Lake-Area-of-Alberta.pdf|accessdate=2 December 2016}}</ref>
Chuck Masters of the [[United States Geological Survey|USGS]] estimates that, "Taken together, these resource occurrences, in the [[Western Hemisphere]], are approximately equal to the Identified Reserves of conventional crude oil accredited to the Middle East."<ref>{{cite web <!-- is it reliable source? --> |url= http://www.runet.edu/~wkovarik/oil/3unconventional.html |title= The oil reserve fallacy: Proven reserves are not a measure of future supply |author= Kovarik, Bill |accessdate=11 July 2009}}</ref> Authorities familiar with the resources believe that the world's ultimate reserves of unconventional oil are several times as large as those of conventional oil and will be highly profitable for companies as a result of higher prices in the 21st century.<ref>{{cite journal | first = Maurice | last = Dusseault | title = Emerging Technology for Economic Heavy Oil Development | publisher = [[Ministry of Energy (Alberta)|Alberta Department of Energy]] | year = 2002 | url = http://www.energy.gov.ab.ca/OilSands/pdfs/RPT_Chops_app2.pdf | format = PDF | accessdate =24 May 2008}}</ref> In October 2009, the [[United States Geological Survey|USGS]] updated the Orinoco tar sands (Venezuela) recoverable "mean value" to {{convert|513|Goilbbl|m3}}, with a 90% chance of being within the range of 380-{{convert|652|Goilbbl}}, making this area "one of the world's largest recoverable oil accumulations".<ref name="USGS Venezuela">{{cite web|url=http://pubs.usgs.gov/fs/2009/3028/pdf/FS09-3028.pdf|title=An Estimate of Recoverable Heavy Oil Resources of the Orinoco Oil Belt, Venezuela|author1=Christopher J. Schenk |author2=Troy A. Cook |author3=Ronald R. Charpentier |author4=Richard M. Pollastro |author5=Timothy R. Klett |author6=Marilyn E. Tennyson |author7=Mark A. Kirschbaum |author8=Michael E. Brownfield |author9=Janet K. Pitman. |last-author-amp=yes |date=11 January 2010|publisher=USGS|accessdate=23 January 2010}}</ref>
[[File:Total World Oil Reserves Conventional Unconventional.png|thumb|Unconventional resources are much larger than conventional ones.<ref>{{cite journal | author = Alboudwarej, Hussein| title = Highlighting Heavy Oil | journal = Oilfield Review | date = Summer 2006 | url = http://www.slb.com/~/media/Files/resources/oilfield_review/ors06/sum06/heavy_oil.pdf | format = PDF | accessdate = 24 May 2008 | display-authors = etal}}</ref>]]
Despite the large quantities of oil available in non-conventional sources, Matthew Simmons argued in 2005 that limitations on production prevent them from becoming an effective substitute for conventional crude oil. Simmons stated "these are high energy intensity projects that can never reach high volumes" to offset significant losses from other sources.<ref name="wood052005"> {{cite news|url=http://www.resourceinvestor.com/News/2005/5/Pages/Oil-Doomsday-is-Nigh--Tar-Sands-Not-a-Substitute.aspx|title=Oil Doomsday is Nigh, Tar Sands Not a Substitute|last=Wood|first=Tim |date= 5 November 2005|publisher=Resource Investor|accessdate=11 July 2009}}</ref> Another study claims that even under highly optimistic assumptions, "Canada's oil sands will not prevent peak oil," although production could reach {{convert|5000000|oilbbl/d|abbr=on}} by 2030 in a "crash program" development effort.<ref name=SoumlEtAl2007>{{cite journal | format = PDF | doi = 10.1016/j.enpol.2006.06.007 |author1=Söderbergh, B. |author2=Robelius, F. |author3=Aleklett, K. | journal = Energy Policy | volume = 35 | issue = 3 | pages = 1931–1947 | year = 2007 | title = A crash programme scenario for the Canadian oil sands industry }}</ref>
Moreover, oil extracted from these sources typically contains contaminants such as [[sulfur]] and [[heavy metals]] that are energy-intensive to extract and can leave [[tailings]], ponds containing hydrocarbon sludge, in some cases.<ref name = "MJ Herald"/><ref>{{cite journal |title=Downhole heavy crude oil hydroprocessing |journal=Applied Catalysis A: General |last1=Weissman | first1=Jeffrey G. |last2=Kessler |first2=Richard V. |date=20 June 1996 |volume=140 |issue=1 |pages= 1–16 |issn = 0926-860X |doi=10.1016/0926-860X(96)00003-8}}</ref> The same applies to much of the [[Middle East]]'s undeveloped conventional oil reserves, much of which is heavy, viscous, and contaminated with sulfur and metals to the point of being unusable.<ref>{{cite journal | first = David | last = Fleming | title = After Oil | journal = Prospect Magazine | year = 2000 | url = http://www.prospectmagazine.co.uk/2000/11/afteroil/ | accessdate =20 December 2009}}</ref> However, [[oil price increases since 2003|high oil prices]] make these sources more financially appealing.<ref name=nyt08212005/> A study by Wood Mackenzie suggests that by the early 2020s all the world's extra oil supply is likely to come from unconventional sources.<ref>{{cite news |url=http://www.ft.com/cms/s/0/11ba213e-bf7e-11db-9ac2-000b5df10621.html|title=Study sees harmful hunt for extra oil |work=[[Financial Times]]|author=Hoyos, Carola|date=18 February 2007| accessdate =11 July 2009}}</ref>
===Production=== {{Main|Petroleum|Means of production|Extraction of petroleum}} The point in time when peak global oil production occurs defines peak oil. Some adherents of 'peak oil' believe that production capacity will remain the main limitation of supply, and that when production decreases, it will be the main [[bottleneck (logistics)|bottleneck]] to the petroleum [[supply and demand|supply/demand]] equation.<ref>{{cite journal|first1=Murray J. |last1=King D.|title=Climate policy: Oil's tipping point has passed.|journal=Nature|date=2012|volume=481|issue=7382|pages=433–435|doi= 10.1038/481433a|url=http://www.nature.com/nature/journal/v481/n7382/full/481433a.html|accessdate=23 September 2015|pmid=22281577}}</ref> Others believe that the increasing industrial effort to extract oil will have a negative effect on global economic growth, leading to demand contraction and a price collapse,<ref name="How Economic Growth Fails"/><ref>{{cite web|last1=Tverberg|first1=Gail|title=What's Ahead? Lower Oil Prices, Despite Higher Extraction Costs|url=http://ourfiniteworld.com/2013/11/15/whats-ahead-lower-oil-prices-despite-higher-extraction-cost/|website=Our Finite World|accessdate=10 January 2016|date=2013-11-15}}</ref> thereby causing production decline as some unconventional sources become uneconomical. Yet others believe that the peak may be to some extent led by declining demand as new technologies and improving efficiency shift energy usage away from oil.
Worldwide oil discoveries have been less than annual production since 1980.<ref name=ewg1007/> World population has grown faster than oil production. Because of this, oil production ''[[per capita]]'' peaked in 1979 (preceded by a plateau during the period of 1973–1979).<ref name="RCDuncan2001">{{cite journal | last = Duncan | first = Richard C |date=November 2001 | title = The Peak of World Oil Production and the Road to the Olduvai Gorge | journal = [[Population and Environment]] | issn = 1573-7810 | volume = 22 | issue = 5 | pages = 503–522 | doi = 10.1023/A:1010793021451 | url = http://dieoff.org/page224.htm |accessdate=11 July 2009}}</ref>
[[File:Countries by Oil Production in 2013.svg|450px|thumb|center|550px|Countries producing oil 2013, bbl/day (CIA World Factbook)]] [[File:Oil producing countries map.png|thumb|center|550px|Oil producing [[List of countries by oil production|countries]] (information from 2006–2012)]]
The increasing investment in harder-to-reach oil as of 2005 was said to signal oil companies' belief in the end of easy oil.<ref name=bostonglobe122005/> While it is widely believed that increased oil prices spur an increase in production, an increasing number of oil industry insiders were reportedly coming to believe in 2009 that even with higher prices, oil production was unlikely to increase significantly. Among the reasons cited were both geological factors as well as "above ground" factors that are likely to see oil production plateau.<ref name=reuters010908>{{cite news |url=https://www.reuters.com/article/ousiv/idUSL0725705620080109?sp=true |title=Tough to pump more oil, even at $100 |author1=Mackey, Peg |author2=Lawler, Alex |agency=Reuters |date=9 January 2008 |accessdate=11 July 2009}}</ref>
A 2008 ''Journal of Energy Security'' analysis of the energy return on drilling effort ([[energy returned on energy invested]], also referred to as EROEI) in the United States concluded that there was extremely limited potential to increase production of both gas and (especially) oil. By looking at the historical response of production to variation in drilling effort, the analysis showed very little increase of production attributable to increased drilling. This was because of diminishing returns with increasing drilling effort: as drilling effort increased, the energy obtained per active [[drill rig]] was reduced according to a severely diminishing [[power law]]. The study concluded that even an enormous increase of drilling effort was unlikely to significantly increase oil and gas production in a mature petroleum region such as the United States.<ref name="TDKailing2008">{{cite journal | last = Kailing | first = Timothy D | date = 14 December 2008 | title = Can the United States Drill Its Way to Energy Security? | journal = Journal of Energy Security | url = http://www.ensec.org/index.php?option=com_content&view=article&id=166:can-us-drill-its-way-to-energy-security&catid=90:energysecuritydecember08&Itemid=334/ |accessdate=11 July 2009}}</ref> However, contrary to the study's conclusion, since the analysis was published in 2008, US production of crude oil has increased 86%, and production of dry natural gas has increased 34% (2015 compared to 2008).<ref>US Energy Information Administration, [http://www.eia.gov/dnav/pet/hist/LeafHandler.ashx?n=pet&s=mcrfpus1&f=a US crude oil production], accessed 16 May 2013.</ref>
The assumption of inevitable declining volumes of oil and gas produced per unit of effort is contrary to recent experience in the US. In the United States, as of 2017, there has been an ongoing decade-long increase in the productivity of oil and gas drilling in all the major tight oil and gas plays. The US Energy Information Administration reports, for instance, that in the Bakken Shale production area of North Dakota, the volume of oil produced per day of drilling rig time in January 2017 was 4 times the oil volume per day of drilling five years previous, in January 2012, and nearly 10 times the oil volume per day of ten years previous, in January 2007. In the Marcellus gas region of the northeast, The volume of gas produced per day of drilling time in January 2017 was 3 times the gas volume per day of drilling five years previous, in January 2012, and 28 times the gas volume per day of drilling ten years previous, in January 2007.<ref>US Energy Information Administration, [https://www.eia.gov/petroleum/drilling/ Drilling productivity report], 15 May 2017, (see “Report data” spreadsheet).</ref>
====Anticipated production by major agencies==== [[File:2012 Crude Oil Export Treemap.png|thumb|300px|Crude oil export treemap (2012) from Harvard Atlas of Economic Complexity<ref>{{cite web|url=http://atlas.cid.harvard.edu/explore/tree_map/export/show/all/2709/2012/|title=Who exported Petroleum oils, crude in 2012? – The Atlas Of Economic Complexity|work=harvard.edu}}</ref>]]
Average yearly gains in global supply from 1987 to 2005 were {{convert|1.2|Moilbbl/d}} (1.7%).<ref name="IEA:World Oil Supply and Demand">{{cite journal |url=http://omrpublic.iea.org/omrarchive/18jan07tab.pdf |format=PDF |title=World oil supply and demand |publisher=[[International Energy Agency]] |date=18 January 2007 |accessdate=28 July 2009}}</ref> In 2005, the IEA predicted that 2030 production rates would reach {{convert|120000000|oilbbl/d}}, but this number was gradually reduced to {{convert|105000000|oilbbl/d}}. A 2008 analysis of IEA predictions questioned several underlying assumptions and claimed that a 2030 production level of {{convert|75000000|oilbbl/d}} (comprising {{convert|55000000|oilbbl}} of crude oil and {{convert|20000000|oilbbl}} of both non-conventional oil and [[natural gas liquids]]) was more realistic than the IEA numbers.<ref name=alklett112009/> More recently, the EIA's Annual Energy Outlook 2015 indicated no production peak out to 2040. However, this required a future Brent crude oil price of $US144/bbl (2013 dollars) "as growing demand leads to the development of more costly resources".<ref>{{cite web|title=Annual Energy Outlook 2015|url=https://www.eia.gov/pressroom/presentations/sieminski_05042015.pdf|website=EIA|publisher=Energy Information Administration|accessdate=21 April 2016}}</ref> Whether the world economy can grow and maintain demand for such a high oil price remains to be seen.
====Oil field decline==== [[File:Alaska Crude Oil Production.PNG|thumb|Alaska's oil production has declined 70% since peaking in 1988]]
